comment._content: goo.gl/F0gL <--google maps view of Broadway North from Worth Street for comparison. Looks like a couple of buildings are still there :)

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: The writing at the bottom of the negative points out the gas line up on trestles. (With one mystery word still to decipher:) "B[road]way from so[uth] of Worth St. looking no[rth]. Shows [flanked?] street elevated gas." Might relate to this New York Times story about the gas main running above ground during subway construction, query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9F0DE...

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
I noticed that there also was a pipe laid along the gutter at left -- probably one of the curbside gas mains mentioned in the NYT story.

I'm unable to get my mind out of the gutter:

Here's another Bain/LOC photo (posted on May 28) that shows an exposed pipeline in the NYC gutter. It's a December photo; if the pipe carried water, it would freeze:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4647771622/]

They say that New York City is a gas, all year 'round -- if one of those pipes had ruptured, that would have been the literal truth.

[Insert joke about NYC's exploding population, here.]

comment.author: 15283643@N04

comment._content: There is an interesting stack of 4-chambered, square conduits under the trestle.
